item.title: Iraqi Forces Fighting ISIS for Ramadi Push Toward City Center
item.description: Soldiers began a fierce assault against the Islamic State, and by Tuesday evening had reached the edges of the city center despite heavy resistance.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: OMAR AL-JAWOSHY, SEWELL CHAN and KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: Iraqi soldiers in northern Ramadi, Iraq, on Monday.

item.title: Unseasonable Greetings in a New York Searching for Jack Frost
item.description: The city has been so warm that the average temperature for the month could be 14 degrees above normal, the largest such deviation on record, and the high for Dec. 24 is forecast to be 72.
item.dc:creator: ANDY NEWMAN
item.media:credit: Christopher Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Abe Schoener, 54, at the farmers’ market in Union Square in Manhattan last week, near booths that sell Christmas decorations.

item.title: Ruling Could Help Washington Redskins in Trademark Case
item.description: A federal appeals court, in a case involving an Asian-American dance-rock band, struck down part of a law that let the government reject trademarks it deemed offensive or disparaging to others.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD SANDOMIR
item.media:description: Washington helmets before a game in October. The Redskins are trying to reverse the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office’s cancellation of six registered trademarks to their name.

item.title: Robert Durst to Be Extradited for Murder Charge
item.description: Mr. Durst, an estranged member of a prominent New York real-estate family, is accused of killing a friend in 2000.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: In the Dirtiest Cities, Air Pollution Forces Life Changes
item.description: Residents of some of the world’s most heavily polluted cities shared their experiences dealing with the daily challenges and consequences.
item.dc:creator: SONA PATEL
item.media:description: Smog on the outskirts in New Delhi last year. Life in the world's most polluted cities presents an array of challenges and perils for residents.

item.title: Patients Fear Spike in Price of Old Drugs
item.description: A showdown between two drug companies, one that gives away a treatment for a rare disease and another looking to profit from it, illustrates the growing tension over the rising prices of drugs.
item.dc:creator: SABRINA TAVERNISE
item.media:credit: Brad Swonetz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fred Kellerman's life was changed by a free drug that treated his Lambert-Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome. He and other patients are fearful that they will not be able to afford it if a pharmaceutical company gets exclusive rights to sell it from the F.D.A.

item.title: Virginia to Stop Recognizing Concealed Gun Permits From 25 States
item.description: In a stark change in policy for a state known for its expansive gun rights, Virginia’s attorney general announced that the state was revoking its reciprocity agreements with 25 states.
item.dc:creator: SHERYL GAY STOLBERG

item.title: Swimmer Rethinks Her Course After a National Breakthrough
item.description: Courtney Bartholomew, a decorated senior at the University of Virginia, cannot afford to continue swimming much longer without endorsements or sponsorships.
item.dc:creator: KAREN CROUSE
item.media:description: Courtney Bartholomew after breaking the American short-course record in the 100-meter backstroke this month in Indianapolis.

item.title: U.S. Says Hacker Stole IDs and Unreleased Scripts From Host of Celebrities
item.description: The charges against Alonzo Knowles illustrate the ease with which private email contacts, even for security-conscious entertainers, can be exploited.
item.dc:creator: BENJAMIN MUELLER

item.title: Start-Up Personalizes Books for Children, With Robot as Co-Author
item.description: A mediocre gift inspired the creation of Lost My Name, a start-up that personalizes books for hundreds of thousands of young readers.
item.dc:creator: ALEXANDRA ALTER
item.media:description: Lost My Name, a company run by, from left, Tal Oron, Asi Sharabi, Pedro Serapicos and David Cadji-Newby, uses code to create individualized children’s books.

item.title: 1950s U.S. Nuclear Target List Offers Chilling Insight
item.description: A list of the United States’ potential targets in the event of war with the Soviet Union shows that while many were industrial facilities and government buildings, one for each city was simply designated “Population.”
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: SCOTT SHANE
item.media:description: A deactivated Titan II nuclear missile in May at the Titan Missile Museum in Green Valley, Ariz.

item.title: Critic's Notebook: For Larry Wilmore, a Wagging Finger Replaces a Wink on ‘The Nightly Show’
item.description: In a mock-news ecosystem typically defined by slick jabs and arched eyebrows, Mr. Wilmore’s show often reveals a tone of exasperation.
item.category: The Nightly Show With Larry Wilmore (TV Program)
item.dc:creator: JON CARAMANICA
item.media:description: A scene from “The Nightly Show With Larry Wilmore.”

item.title: Sandra Bland’s Family Calls for Criminal Charges Against Texas Trooper
item.description: Though grand jury decided not to indict any jailers in connection with Ms. Bland’s death, the panel could still consider criminal charges against the arresting trooper.
item.dc:creator: MITCH SMITH
item.media:credit: Rich Hein/Sun-Times Media, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Cannon Lambert, left, a lawyer for Sandra Bland's family, at a news conference in Chicago on Monday, the day a Texas grand jury decided not to issue indictments in connection with Ms. Bland's death.

item.title: First Draft: Donald Trump Goes Vulgar in Swipe at Hillary Clinton
item.description: Donald J. Trump used a vulgar reference to male anatomy when referring to Hillary Clinton’s 2008 campaign and he mocked her prolonged bathroom break at Saturday’s Democratic debate.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL BARBARO
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump at a campaign rally in Grand Rapids, Mich., on Monday.

item.title: First Draft: Analysis of Donald Trump Tax Plan Sees a Boon for Wealthy and Trillions in Debt
item.description: Donald J. Trump has said that he would use his deal-making prowess to reduce costs and pay for his tax cuts and programs, though an analysis of his plan by the Tax Policy Center sees a benefit for the wealthiest Americans and trillions of dollars in new debt.
item.dc:creator: ALAN RAPPEPORT
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump at a campaign rally in Grand Rapids, Mich., on Monday.

item.title: Songkick Sues Live Nation, Saying It Abuses Its Market Power
item.description: Songkick’s lawsuit asserts that Live Nation and Ticketmaster pressure artists not to do business with the smaller ticketing company.
item.dc:creator: BEN SISARIO
item.media:description: Paul McCartney is among the acts Songkick has worked with.

item.title: New York Detective Killed in Afghanistan Is Mourned as an ‘Unassuming Hero’
item.description: The death of Joseph Lemm, who died in a suicide bombing along with five other Americans, was felt throughout the Police Department as well as in his Nebraska hometown.
item.dc:creator: J. DAVID GOODMAN and AL BAKER
item.media:description: Detective Joseph Lemm, a 15-year veteran of the Police Department, was on his third tour of duty in the Middle East.

item.title: As TV Ad Rates Soar, ‘Super PACs’ Pivot to Core Campaign Work
item.description: The groups, conceived as a way to raise and spend unlimited amounts of money on television, are now overseeing nuts-and-bolts jobs like field operations and data collection.
item.dc:creator: NICK CORASANITI and MATT FLEGENHEIMER
item.media:credit: Ian Thomas Jansen-Lonnquist for The New York Times
item.media:description: Carly Fiorina, a Republican presidential candidate, signs a placard for Carly for America, the "super PAC" supporting her, in New Hampshire last month. The super PAC handles advance work, ground operations, merchandise sales and volunteer lists.

item.title: Election Results in Spain Are a Stinging End to Europe’s Year
item.description: In 2016, Brussels, Berlin and international creditors will have fewer friends to turn to after a series of elections that have hollowed out Europe’s political center.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE and ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece at a meeting in Brussels in October.

item.title: Syrian Peace Talks Planned for January, U.N. Official Says
item.description: Representatives of the Syrian government and its opponents will participate, United Nations officials said, without providing details.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
